page.title: 18Local Names
page.content: Old farms and houses are sometimes named from obvious landmarks, but more often after early tenants. The origin of Gay Street and Gaywood may be John de Gaynesford, who made tax returns in the early 14th century. Harbolets is a diminutive of Herbert; the old house replaces a 14th C farm. Horelands may derive from Hollands, as there was a de Hollande. Saucelands probably derives from Galpho Sauce, who paid tax in 1296. The most likely theory for the name 'Blue Idol' arises because pieces of blue porcelain, undoubtedly old, were dug up there. These may have come from a statue of the Virgin Mary, as the area was staunchly Catholic. Several farmers use the Sussex dialect word 'rew' when talking of a hedge cum ditch. See "A Dictionary of the Sussex Dialect" by Helena Hall (1981).
